Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 For repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.

ALLEGATION:
It is alleged that the facility restrained a youth 4 times between 9/21-9/25, 2021
when there were no indications of risk of harm to self or others.
INVESTIGATION:
On September 27, 2021, a special investigation was initiated into the allegation
described above. Staff and a resident were interviewed. Documents were also
reviewed. What follows is information obtained from the aforementioned sources.
2

On September 28, 2021, the Vice President of Treatment Programs was notified on
site of the complaint and the initiation of a special investigation.
On September 28, 2021, the Program Supervisor of the DHHS referring office was
notified of the complaint and that a special investigation had been initiated.
Each of the four incidents, staff interviewed, and documents reviewed, will be
addressed separately for clarity.
Incident # 1. Incident #1 occurred on September 21, 2021.
On November 29, 2021, and December 28, 2021, Staff 1 was interviewed. Staff 1 is
a direct care Youth Specialist. Staff 1 reported that on the date of the incident Youth
A, had become disruptive while in classroom of Ashmun school. Youth A had
climbed on top of a classroom desk and refused to get down when directed and
began swearing at Staff 1. Staff 1 reported that when Youth A refused to get down
from the desk she took hold of Youth A’s hand and Youth A hopped down from the
desk but then climbed back up onto the desk, refusing to get down. Staff 1 reported
that Youth A was not standing on the desk but crouched on all fours. Staff 1 reported
that she felt it was a safety issue for Youth A to remain on top of the desk. Staff 1
reported that she then asked the classroom teacher to take the rest of the residents
out of the classroom. Youth A then got down from the table with a Level 1 extended
arm hold initiated by Staff 1. Staff 1 reported that Youth A then began spitting on her
and per her safety plan initiated a benevolent restraint. Staff 1 reported that she
could not recall if Youth A had attempted to hit her or not. Staff 1 reported that when
she then initiated the one person restraint Youth A dropped her body weight and
Staff 1 released her from the restraint. Staff 1 reported that Youth A was restrained
again when she took hold of a piece of a window blind and was trying to hit staff with
it as well as trying to kick staff.
Staff 1 was asked, not specific to the incident described above, but in general, why a
second staff person would take hold of a Youth’s other arm thus placing a youth in a
two person Level 1 extended arm hold. Staff 1 reported that the hold on the second
arm prevents Youth A from hitting staff.
On November 29. 2021, Staff 2, a Youth Specialist, was interviewed. Staff 2
reported that when she entered the classroom Youth A was down from the table and
she tried to de-escalate Youth A. Staff 2 reported that she approached Youth A from
behind and took hold of Youth A’s arms and attempted to rotate her away from the
staff she was spitting on. Staff 2 reported that Youth A pulled away from her and
began swearing and resumed spitting and swearing at staff. Staff 2 reported that she
attended to the rest of the youth, who had been removed from the classroom, as
Staff 1 and Staff 3 restrained Youth A.
3

On November 22, 2021, and December 28, 2021, Staff 3, a Youth Specialist, was
interviewed. Staff 3 reported that when she entered that classroom Youth A was
escalated and was kicking at staff and spitting. Staff 3 reported that proximity control
was attempted to prevent Youth A from kicking staff. Proximity control is described
by staff as not placing hands on but blocking a youth from exiting a room’s doorway
or standing in front of a youth who may be attempting to engage another youth or
staff in an aggressive manner. Staff 3 reported that a two person Level 1 extended
arm hold was initiated by herself and Staff 1 and then transitioned into a benevolent
restraint.
On December 1, 2021, Staff 4, a Youth Specialist, was interviewed. Staff 4 reported
that when he entered the classroom youth were exiting except for Youth A who was
escalated. Staff 4 reported that Youth A was grabbing pencils and throwing them as
Staff 1 was trying to deescalate Youth A. Staff 4 reported that Youth A was trying to
exit the classroom and he stood in front of doors preventing her from doing so. Staff
4 reported at one point Youth A had ripped window blinds partially off and was trying
to use a piece of the blind to hit him. Staff 4 reported that Youth A was then placed
in a benevolent restraint.
DOCUMENT REVIEW:
Incident Report dated September 21, 2021, was reviewed. Staff 1 acknowledged
that she wrote the incident report. The incident report states in part, “{Youth A}
started spitting in {Staff 1’s} face, per her safety plan that {Staff 5} created, {Staff 1}
attempted a Benevolent Restraint at 12:21pm.” The incident report further states,
“Youth A continued to kick, {Staff 1} and {Staff 3} transitioned into a Level 1
extended arm hold at 12:23pm.”
Incident # 2. Incident # 2 occurred on September 22, 2021.
On September 22, 2021, and November 22, 2021, the Finance and Quality Program
Manager was interviewed. The Finance and Quality Program Manager reported the
following. On September 22, 2021, Youth A had left Hainley House and was sitting
down in the administrative parking lot. The Finance and Quality Program Manager
reported that there was concern for the safety of Youth A as she was sitting in the
parking lot near where the driveway to the parking lot rises up a hill. The Finance
and Quality Program Manager reported that delivery trucks come up the driveway at
speeds that are not always safe or appropriate and despite speed limit postings. The
Finance and Quality Control Manager reported that Youth A was refusing to leave
the parking lot so a Level 1 extended arm escort on both arms was initiated by
herself and Staff 3 to escort Youth A out of the parking lot and into Leppien House.
The Finance and Quality Program Manager reported that Staff 6, a Residential
Team Supervisor, also provided additional support. The Finance and Quality
Program Manager reported that Youth A became assaultive, kicking and stomping
on her feet and Youth A was then transitioned into a benevolent restraint and then to
an Aegis safety position.
4

The Finance and Quality Control Manager was asked why a two person Level 1
extended arm hold would be used. She reported that control of Youth A’s free arm is
to prevent Youth A from hitting staff or others. The Finance and Quality Control
Manager reported that a youth has freedom of movement when in the Level 1
extended arm hold, specifically that a youth can walk freely and to wherever.
On November 22, 2021, and December 28, 2021, Staff 3 was interviewed, Staff 3
reported that Youth A had ran out of Leppien House and into the administrative
parking lot. Staff 3 reported that she followed Youth A into the parking lot area. Staff
3 reported that traffic and cars are an issue in that area of the parking lot. Staff 3
reported that she and the Finance and Quality Control Manager initiated a two arm
Level 1 extended are escort to remove Youth A from the parking lot for her safety.
Staff 3 reported that she switched out the hold on Youth A with Staff 6 because she
was losing her grip on the arm of Youth A. Staff 3 reported that once inside Leppien
House Youth A escalated further and was assaultive and was subsequently
restrained.
On September 28, 2021, and November 22, 2021, Staff 6, was interviewed. Staff 6
reported that he observed Staff 3 and the Finance and Quality Control Manager had
placed an extended Level 1 extended arm hold on Youth A in the administrative
parking lot of the facility. Staff 6 reported that he assisted with the Level 1 extended
arm hold and escorting Youth A out of the parking lot and into Leppien House. Staff
6 reported that Youth A was restrained inside the house when she became
assaultive.
On September 28, 2021, and December 13, 2021, Youth A was interviewed
regarding the incident. Youth A is a 11 year old female. Youth A reported that she
was sitting in the facility parking lot and Staff 6 took hold of her to stand and walked
her back to Leppien House. Youth A could not provide any other details.
Observation of parking lot and area where the incident occurred: I observed,
with the Finance and Quality Control Manager, the area where Youth A had been
sitting in the administrative parking lot. Youth A was sitting near the top of the
driveway hill as it enters the parking lot. From the bottom of the hill into the parking
lot it could be difficult to see a child or person sitting on the pavement.
DOCUMENT REVIEW:
Incident Report dated September 22, 2021, was reviewed. The incident report
documents that Youth A was sitting in the administrative parking lot refusing to leave
and re-enter Leppien House. The Finance and Quality Control Manager and Staff 3
placed Youth A in a two person Level 1 extended arm hold to escort her from the
parking lot to Leppien House.
5

Incident # 3. Incident # 3 occurred on September 23, 2021.
On November 22, 2021, and December 28, 2021, Staff 3 was interviewed, Staff 3
reported that Youth A had left Hainley House and was able to enter Ashmun
Academy. Staff 3 reported that Youth A was swearing and disrupting school and she
placed Youth A in a Level 1 extended arm hold to escort her out of the school. Staff
3 reported that Staff 7 assisted by placing Youth A’s other arm in the Level 1
extended arm hold. Staff 3 was asked why two staff would be needed to escort
Youth A. Staff 3 reported that Youth A can be assaultive and the second arm hold is
to prevent Youth A from assaulting staff. Staff 3 reported that Youth A was then
placed into a benevolent restraint as she was kicking staff.
On September 28, 2021, and December 13, 2021, Youth A was interviewed
regarding the incident. Youth A reported that she was restrained by Staff 3 because
she ran into the school when she was not supposed to be there.
DOCUMENT REVIEW:
Incident report dated September 23, 2021, was reviewed. The incident report
documents that Youth A was placed in a two person Level 1 extended arm hold to
escort her from the classroom to prevent her from disturbing other youth in the
school classroom.
Incident # 4. Incident # 4 occurred on September 25, 2021.
On November 22, 2021, Staff 8 was interviewed. Staff 8 reported Youth A was in the
staff office and was refusing to follow directives to exit the office. Staff 8 reported
that she could not remember if Youth A was attempting to get something in the office
to self-harm with. Staff 8 reported that she and Staff 1 placed Youth A in a two
person Level 1 extended arm escort to remove her from the office. Staff 8 reported
that Youth A was released once out of the office and she began running towards unit
doors and was attempting to assault staff and was placed in a benevolent restraint
by Staff 1. Staff 8 was asked if the Level 1 extended arm escort is restrictive, and
she acknowledged that it is.
On November 29, 2021, and December 28, 2021, Staff 1 was interviewed regarding
the incident. The incident report was read for Staff 1 for a review of the incident.
Staff 1 reported that she could not remember what Youth A was doing in the staff
office but acknowledged that a two person Level 1 extended arm escort was used to
remove Youth A from the staff office. Youth A was released from the escort and she
began running towards unit doors and at one point was trying to hit Staff 8 and was
subsequently placed in a benevolent restraint.
DOCUMENT REVIEW:
Incident report dated September 25, 2021, was reviewed. The incident report
states in part, “Due to previous incidents and her safety plan along with safety
6

concerns (she has been trying to bust down the doors to the office). {Staff 1} gave
{Youth A} choices either to walk out of the office on her own or be escorted out of
the office. {Youth A} refused and told staff to both fuck off. {Staff 1} and {Staff 8}
placed {Youth A} in a Level 1 extended arm escort at 5:11pm and escorted her out
of the office.”
Eagle Village Sherk House Behavior Support Plan. The support plan for Youth A,
dated August 23, 2021, was reviewed. The plan states, in part, the following:
“4. If {Youth A} begins to pick up rocks, demonstrates she is beginning to take her
clothes off, or is within 20 feet of any building or vehicle staff are to utilize the
following immediately;
a. Mirror and matching
b. Use an escort
c. Place in the Therapeutic restraint.
On December 14, 2021, Staff 5, the therapist for Youth A, was interviewed. Staff 5
acknowledged that she created the behavior support plan for Youth A. Staff 5
reported that the plan is to prevent property destruction and self harm. Staff 5
reported that glass from broken windows is a safety concern and therefore the plan
stipulates preventing Youth A from getting within 20 feet of vehicles or buildings
where she can throw rocks at windows. Staff 5 reported that placing Youth A in a
therapeutic restraint is the last resort option. Staff 5 reported that a restraint is
justified if Youth A begins to take her clothes off. Staff 5 reported that spitting is not
justification for a restraint.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4159 Resident restraint.
(4) The written policy shall only permit the licensee to
restrain a child for the following circumstances:
(a) To prevent injury to the child, self-injury, or injury to
others.
(b) As a precaution against escape or truancy.
(c) When there is serious destruction of property that
places a child or others at serious threat of violence
or injury if no intervention occurs.
7

ANALYSIS: Incident # 1. Staff 1 reported in the original interview on
November 29, 2021, that she initiated a restraint of Youth A as
Youth A had begun spitting on her. In a subsequent interview
Staff 1 could not recall if Youth A had become assaultive prior to
the restraint. The incident report written by Staff 1 documents
that a restraint was initiated by Staff 1 when Youth A began
spitting. The restraint was unjustified as harm to self and others
was not present.
Incident # 2. The Finance and Quality Control Manager and
Staff 3 reported that Youth A was placed in a Level 1 extended
arm escort to remove her from an area of the administrative
parking due to safety concerns regarding vehicle traffic. I
observed the area where the incident occurred and Youth A
sitting on the pavement in that area presented a safety concern.
The restraint was justified for safety reasons.
Incident # 3. Staff 3 and Staff 7 initiated a two person Level 1
extended arm hold to remove Youth A from the Ashmun
academy where Youth A had gained entrance. Staff 3 reported
that Youth A was disruptive and swearing while in the school.
The incident report indicates that Youth A was removed from the
school using the two person hold as she was disruptive. Staff 3
reported that the two person extended arm hold is used as
Youth A can be assaultive. Youth A was not presenting a safety
concern when she was placed in the two person extended arm
hold. The restraint was unjustified.
Incident # 4. Youth A was placed in a two person Level 1
extended arm hold by Staff 1 and Staff 8 to remove her from the
staff office. Staff 1 and Staff 8 could not recall if Youth A was
engaging in self-harm behaviors which required the hold. Staff 8
reported that the escort hold is restrictive.
During this investigation Staff 1, Staff 3, and the Finance and
Quality Control Manager reported that control of both arms of
Youth A is used to prevent her from hitting. The incident report
documents that Youth A was placed in the two person Level 1
extended arm hold to remove her from the office. There is no
evidence that Youth A was engaging in harm to self or others
when she was placed in the extended arm hold. The restraint
was unjustified.
The staff control of the second arm of Youth A in anticipation of
Youth A becoming assaultive ceases to be an escort and is a
8

restraint. Anticipating Youth A becoming assaultive as a reason
for the restraint lacks justification for the restraint.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
While the facility’s behavior management model terms the two
person hold as an escort, if it is not permitting the youth to have
free movement of their body, it is by Act 116 definition, a
restraint. Therefore, staff should be trained that it is not the
terminology that dictates whether a hold is written up as a
restraint, but the act of restricting the youth’s movement. This
will ensure that when staff go hands on it is documented
correctly.
Additional technical assistance was provided regarding Youth
A’s safety plan.
The plan states, in part, the following:
“4. If {Youth A} begins to pick up rocks, demonstrates she is
beginning to take her clothes off, or is within 20 feet of any
building or vehicle staff are to utilize the following
immediately;
a. Mirror and matching
b. Use an escort
c. Place in the Therapeutic restraint.
The way this is written implies that staff can use a., b., or c if
Youth A is exhibiting the behaviors outlined, which some staff
believed to be the case. It was reported that the therapist
intended this to be a progressive list, not for staff to choose
which one to use. The rule allowance for use of restraint was
reviewed and they were encouraged to remind staff of the rule
requirements and to reword the safety plan to comply with the
rules and create less confusion for staff, in addition to retraining
the staff on the safety plan expectations.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
